title: What Does CTFU Stand For? Definition, Uses & More

steps.content: CTFU means â€œCracking the f*ck upâ€ on text and social media. Itâ€™s most commonly used over text and online platforms like Snapchat, TikTok, and Instagram. steps.title: Use CTFU to convey a sudden, intense burst of laughter.
steps.content: Use CTFU to convey a sudden, intense burst of laughter. When you want someone to know that whatever they messaged you was super funny and made you laugh, send them CTFU in response. Since it means â€œCracking the f*ck up,â€ sending this acronym to someone (or writing it as a comment on a social media post) makes it pretty clear that they tickled your funny bone! steps.title: Share something funny with a friend using CTFU.
steps.content: Share something funny with a friend using CTFU. If you come across something hilarious like a video or meme or just have a silly story to share, send it to a friend and pair it with CTFU. That way, they can see right off the bat that whatever you sent them is intended to make them laugh (and itâ€™s already making you laugh). steps.title: Use CTFU to replace similar acronyms like LOL or ROFL.
steps.content: Use CTFU to replace similar acronyms like LOL or ROFL. CTFU is synonymous with LOL ("laughing out loud") and ROFL ("rolling on the floor laughing"). All 3 acronyms are used to express laughterâ€”so if you feel like updating your text slang and using a newer term, try replacing some of those LOLs and ROFLs with CTFU. Them: â€œLOL'd so hard when I saw this meme!!â€ You: â€œIâ€™m CTFU thatâ€™s hilarious! ğŸ˜†â€

steps.title: React to their laughter (or change the subject if you prefer).
steps.content: React to their laughter (or change the subject if you prefer). If someone responds to a joke you sent them with CTFU, that means they found it super funny. You might agree with them to show that you share their amusement or simply bring something else up if the joke is over. Decide whether you have anything else to add or you want to talk about something different! Them: â€œCTFU, this is amazing!â€ You: â€œI know, right?? ğŸ¤£ BTW, did you see the pic I sent the other dayâ€¦?â€

steps.title: Send a CTFU of your own to let them know their joke was funny.
steps.content: Send a CTFU of your own to let them know their joke was funny. When someone sends you a joke or funny video and adds CTFU to the message, you might echo them and send CTFU in response to show them that youâ€™re laughing too. I havenâ€™t seen such a goofy-looking dog in a long time!â€ You: â€œOMG!! Iâ€™m also ctfu, this pup is too cute and silly! ğŸ¶â€

steps.title: Start using CTFU too, or keep using terms like LOL and ROFL.
steps.content: Start using CTFU too, or keep using terms like LOL and ROFL. If you notice a friend, acquaintance, or loved one start incorporating CTFU in their social media posts and texts, youâ€™re free to do the same! CTFU is definitely a more recent and trendy term compared to LOL and ROFLâ€”although thereâ€™s nothing wrong with continuing to use the classics if you prefer. Them: â€œMy girlfriend is so unhinged in these pics, Iâ€™m ctfu!!â€ You: â€œCtfu, exactly how much caffeine did she drink today? ğŸ¤£â€

steps.title: CTFU is a strictly casual acronym.
steps.content: CTFU is a strictly casual acronym. Itâ€™s inappropriate to use CTFU in formal or professional messages, not only because it has a swear word in it, but also because itâ€™s considered texting slang. In a setting where spelling and grammar are importantâ€”particularly when youâ€™re messaging a coworker, boss, or professional acquaintanceâ€”itâ€™s a good idea to stick to full words (and clean language) rather than using abbreviations. For example, itâ€™s typically inappropriate to use CTFU in emails to clients or in Instagram posts for an official brand or business account.

steps.title: CTFU may be inappropriate to send to someone who doesnâ€™t swear.
steps.content: CTFU may be inappropriate to send to someone who doesnâ€™t swear. Use your best judgment: if the friend youâ€™re messaging doesnâ€™t swear and feels uncomfortable when they see swear words, itâ€™s not a good idea to use CTFU around them. However, if they have no problem when other people swear (even if they donâ€™t), then itâ€™s fine to use CTFU while texting them. It may also be better to avoid CTFU when messaging someone who doesnâ€™t really use text abbreviations or slang altogether since thereâ€™s a chance they wonâ€™t know what you mean.
